body: New Yorkers usually don't think much about their Sanitation Department unless it does something wrong. That's good reason to point out how it did something right. It looked far ahead and came prepared to a crisis. The predictable closing of the huge Fountain Avenue landfill in Brooklyn will leave the city with only one landfill site, Great Kills in
title: TOPICSBRIGHT IDEAS; FOR ONCE, NO MESS

body: The closing next week of one of the city's last major dump sites, the Fountain Avenue Landfill on Jamaica Bay, will raise the price of dumping garbage and increase the pressure to find alternatives for the 22,000 tons of garbage removed by the City Department of Sanitation each day, sanitation officials said. Moreover, the officials warned that the
title: KEY CITY LANDFILL IS FORCED TO CLOSE, ADDING PRESSURE TO FIND ALTERNATIVES

body: A Federal jury yesterday heard a taped conversation in which Ralph Scopo, a former union leader accused of extorting money from contractors, discussed payments with reputed leaders of the Colombo crime organization. The often-cryptic conversation - secretly recorded at a Brooklyn restaurant in April 1983 by the Federal Bureau of Investigation -
title: COLOMBO JURY HEARS TAPE OF '83 CONVERSATION ABOUT PAYMENTS

body: The House Ways and Means Committee early today voted to continue to allow taxpayers to deduct from their Federal tax returns all state and local income, property and sales tax payments. The vote came as the panel moved toward a final draft of legislation that would make sweeping changes in the Federal income tax system. The bill would lower the top
title: U.S. DEDUCTION FOR LOCAL TAXES VOTED BY PANEL

body: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city had obtained a court order against Black Economic Survival, a group, he said, that ''engages in violent demonstrations at construction sites under the banner of equal-employment opportunity.'' title: THE CITY; Violence Barred At Jobs Protests

body: Thirteen police officers were injured yesterday when demonstrators seeking more construction jobs for minority workers clashed with the police during a protest outside the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the authorities said. Eight protesters were arrested on charges that included assault, incitement to riot, resisting arrest, weapons possession and attempted
title: 13 Police Officers Hurt At a Navy Yard Protest

body: WHEN Frank O'Brien recalls the effect of depth charges, he closes his eyes and lets the memories come flooding back. ''There's almost no way to describe it, the hell it was like,'' said Mr. O'Brien, 61 years old, of East Rutherford. He likened it to ''being in a rolling trash can with somebody outside slamming away with a sledgehammer.'' Mr.
title: SUBMARINERS RECALL THE DANGERS

body: To the Editor: After more than four years of environmental studies and public reviews for the Brooklyn Navy Yard resource-recovery project, which concluded with final approval by New York City's Board of Estimate, it appears there is still confusion about the environmental soundness of this approach to the city's waste-disposal problem. The Navy
title: Experts Back Safety of Navy Yard Waste-Disposal Project

body: To the Editor: As one who gathered more than 150 signatures of New York City voters on petitions to put on the ballot the question of whether nuclear-armed ships should be based in New York Harbor, I was appalled at your Oct. 2 editorial ''Welcome Back the Iowa,'' urging defeat of the referendum. Judging by the reactions I got, the voters of this
title: LETTER: ON NEW YORK HARBOR; THE FOLLY IN A NUCLEAR HOME PORT

title: Welcome Back the Iowa

body: To the Editor: I agree with your Aug. 15 editorial that burning garbage is the most practical available solution for the city's waste-disposal problem. The deep fears these plants engender are not trivial, however, and cannot be dismissed summarily, as you argue. Indeed, despite our years of experience with the process elsewhere, the only
title: Navy Yard Incinerator Endangers Public Health of Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: Please accept this citizen's outrage at ''When the Trash Can't Be Buried'' (editorial, Aug. 15), most specifically at the next-to-last sentence, which suggests that Carol Bellamy and Harrison Goldin ''rise above narrow neighborhood interests'' in objecting to the proposed incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Were the incinerator
title: Navy Yard Incinerator Endangers Public Health of Brooklyn

body: The best way to City Hall is by the steps. At least, that's the premise a lot of groups seemed to be working on yesterday. There was a moment at midday when it seemed as if all of New York had arrived on the venerable City Hall steps to endorse - or to tell off - a mayoral candidate. What's more, they were all talking at once. At the top of the
title: CITY HALL STEPS: A POLITICAL BATTLEFIELD

body: New York City has not fired up a new garbage incineration plant since 1961, largely because of protests from those who would live or work anywhere near such a facility. But now the old Brooklyn Navy Yard has gotten the city's final approval to be home for a state-of-the-art garbage-disposal plant whose 500-foot smokestack would be one of the
title: THE REGION; Brooklyn Garbage Plant Approved

body: The Board of Estimate, rejecting the last-minute appeals of neighborhood residents, gave final city approval yesterday for construction of a garbage-burning incinerator at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard. The incinerator - the first of a network of up to 10 planned across the city at a cost of $2.5 billion - was approved by a 6-to-5 vote after more than
title: APPROVAL IS GIVEN FOR INCINERATOR AT BROOKLYN SITE

body: International South Africa's President rejected foreign and domestic calls for major concessions to the black majority. He also said that he would not soften his terms for the release of Nelson Mandela, the jailed black leader. President P. W. Botha, in defiant and sometimes belligerent tones, told a provincial congress of the governing National
title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 16, 1985

body: Today the New York City Board of Estimate takes up the City Planning Commission's unanimous recommendation to approve a high-temperature incinerator, to be built in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard. There is not enough room in New York City to continue burying 20,000 tons of solid waste a day, nor time to dally further with mythical alternatives. The
title: When the Trash Can't Be Buried

body: Final approval for the construction of a huge incinerator at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, the first stage of the largest new public works project undertaken by the city in years, will be considered tomorrow by the Board of Estimate. The plan, which has divided environmental groups and is opposed by neighbors of the Navy Yard, would transform before
title: DISPUTED INCINERATOR PLAN FOR BROOKLYN NAVY YARD NEAR VOTE

body: In his 158th press release of 1979, Mayor Koch announced that the city had chosen the Brooklyn Navy Yard and an undetermined location in the Bronx as the sites for the city's first two ''resource recovery plants.'' ''It is hoped,'' the release said, ''that the Navy Yard facility could be in operation by 1984, and that a facility in the Bronx could
title: PUBLIC PROJECTS: ARE THEY VIABLE IN THE CITY ANYMORE?

body: Three Democratic candidates for Brooklyn Borough President yesterday challenged the incumbent, Howard Golden, over his acceptance of large campaign donations from real-estate developers and the timing of announcements of several real-estate developments in the borough. Mr. Golden countered that his opponents were jealous of his fund raising, and he
title: GOLDEN AND RIVALS DEBATE DONATIONS

body: Saying that the Koch administration's $1.5 billion plan to build five incinerators would delay a garbage crisis for only seven years, an environmental group yesterday urged the city to greatly expand its plans for recycling. In an 80-page study, the group, the Environmental Defense Fund, said that if the city had to choose between incinerators and
title: GROUP DISPUTES CITY INCINERATOR PLAN

body: A STREET hatch opens onto a steep well of crooked stairs. Below, large spools of colored canvas lean against old tables and sewing machines, while flourescent lights vie for ceiling space with huge pipes. Scissors and awls lie about and pictures of schooners line the walls. This is the underground shop of Frank Martini, the 76-year-old owner and
title: ONE MAN'S ART: BAGS FOR MESSENGERS

title: CALENDAR: RUG HOOKING AND ARCHITECTURE TALK

body: NO SENSE OF IRONY STAINED THE SPECTACLE OF VICtory aboard the U.S.S. Missouri, no sense of shadows to rise years later. We were all too bedazzled by the splendor of the day - for here was American power at its zenith. We had won the war, totally, and the men who had won it, soon to become legend, were all there on the veranda deck in pressed
title: THE DANGER FROM JAPAN

body: A moratorium on garbage-burning incinerators, including those planned in New York City to ease the burden on rapidly filling dumps, was urged today by an influential environmental lobbying group. title: MORATORIUM ON INCINERATORS IS URGED

body: A voluntary garbage recycling program will begin next spring in five residential sections of New York City. The pilot project, announced yesterday at City Hall, calls for residents in the five neighborhoods to separate recyclable refuse, including newspapers, glass and metals, from the garbage. The Sanitation Department will spend $1.5 million for
title: TESTING A PLAN FOR RECYCLING OF CITY TRASH

body: The Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service will wait until October to use a city jail in Brooklyn where 18 Cubans awaiting deportation fought with guards on July 6, according to city officials. The Federal agency has agreed to insure that a representative mix of inmates awaiting deportation are sent to the jail, the Brooklyn Correction
title: U.S. Agency Delays Housing Deportees At Jail in Brooklyn

body: New York's brush with bankruptcy a decade ago has changed not only the city, but also the way the people responsible for the city's future are charting its course into the next century. Decision-makers are being guided by a legacy of lowered expectations about government's ability to solve every problem. They also have to contend with legal
title: '75 BANKRUPTCY SCARE ALTERS CITY PLANS INTO 21ST CENTURY

body: The City Department of Correction said yesterday that it would ask Federal immigration authorities to screen more carefully the detained aliens it sends to a Brooklyn jail where a dozen Cubans awaiting deportation attacked and injured 18 guards Saturday. A department spokesman, Edward Hershey, said city officials would urge United States
title: CITY, CITING REBELLION AT JAIL, TO SEEK CURBS ON DEPORTEES

body: It is decision time for New York City's new resource-recovery plant - a modern solution to the problem of dwindling space for the city's solid wastes. Against understandable but misguided fears that a recovery plant would be a noisome nuisance, the Planning Commission will hear disinterested experts pronounce the proposal sound. It should give
title: Waste No More Time on Waste

body: Fourteen city corrections officers and 12 inmates awaiting deportation to Cuba were injured yesterday during a disturbance at a Brooklyn jail, a Correction Department spokesman said. The fight, which lasted about 10 minutes, took place in a dormitory at the Brooklyn Correctional Facility, which is not designed for inmates who pose a high security
title: 14 JAIL GUARDS AND 12 INMATES INJURED IN FIGHT IN BROOKLYN

title: AS THOUSANDS PROTEST, CITY BACKS TRASH PLANT

title: CITY NOT GETTING NAVY YARD RENT, AN AUDIT FINDS

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

body: Along Bay Street, the crumbled ribbon of boulevard that edges the northern shore of Staten Island, business is slow in the beery saloons. A vacant movie theater stands next to a string of ''antique stores,'' open at odd hours to sell used household goods. But the atmosphere of decay might change soon. title: STATEN ISLAND GETS READY TO GO NAVY

body: The red brick of the sprawling 1,200-unit Clinton Hill Apartments complex in Brooklyn stands out starkly amid the old converted mansions that line Clinton Avenue just east of Fort Greene Park. title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A CONVERSION'S IMPACT ON CLINTON HILL

body: The Reagan Administration has heightened its efforts to transfer a wide range of public assets and programs to private enterprise, and it estimates that the changes will save more than $200 million a year by 1989. As a major part of this strategy, the Administration has identified 11,000 commercial activities to be performed by private contractors
title: U.S. PRESSING PLAN TO CONTRACT WORK

body: To the Editor: In a recent letter to the editor (Jan. 5), Barry Commoner indicated that he would withdraw his opposition to the New York City Sanitation Department's proposed resource-recovery facilities at the Brooklyn Navy Yard if we were to follow California's example and comply with applicable permit conditions concerning dioxin emissions. title: RESOURCE RECOVERY AND DIOXIN: A SAFEGUARD PROVIDED BY LAW
